bullets.text: Russia urged the U.S. to halt pursuit of a fleeing oil tanker, highlighting rising maritime frictions around sanctioned energy flows and enforcement jurisdiction.
Venezuela freed dozens of political prisoners, a potential signal of bargaining toward diplomatic normalization and possible sanctions relief.
Iran protests turned deadly as unrest spread, raising political-stability risk and potential implications for regional security and energy markets.
Guinea’s coup leader won elections after barring major opponents, underscoring democratic backsliding and heightened governance risk for investors in the region.
Japan’s scallop industry became leverage in tensions with China, showing how geopolitical disputes can rapidly weaponize agricultural and seafood trade.
A deadly Swiss Alps resort fire overwhelmed burn centers, forcing cross-border patient transfers and exposing disaster-response capacity constraints in high-income countries.
Finland detained a ship after a critical undersea cable was damaged, reinforcing infrastructure vulnerability risks for European connectivity and security.
Political backlash to the AI data-center boom (power demand, local impacts) signals rising regulatory and electricity-price risk for AI scaling.
Wall Street opened 2026 with dot-com parallels, suggesting investor concern about tech valuation excess and the durability of AI-led earnings expectations.
European banks planning ~200,000 job cuts as AI adoption accelerates, indicating near-term labor displacement and cost-restructuring across financial services.
Singapore’s Q4 GDP surged 5.7% on strong manufacturing, signaling resilient trade-linked growth momentum entering 2026.
Novo Nordisk enters 2026 defending U.S. obesity-drug share, emphasizing high-stakes competitive dynamics in GLP-1 markets and pricing/access battles.
Student-loan forgiveness is taxable again, increasing “tax bomb” planning needs and potentially tightening household cash flow for affected borrowers.
Trump delayed tariffs on cabinets and certain furniture until 2027, temporarily easing housing-related cost pressures and shifting timeline risk for import-exposed firms.
BYD sold 4.6 million vehicles in 2025, meeting a revised goal and underscoring continued scale advantages in the global EV price-and-volume race.
